If he made one movie that approaches a masterwork, it's not Midnight Cowboy, it's Sunday, Bloody Sunday. And even there he can't take a lion's share of the credit, which belongs to actors Peter Finch and Glenda Jackson, and most luminously to the writer of its unforgettable script, Penelope Gilliatt.

Review title: Pretty well made, but nothing spectacular
Review_body: "Midnight Cowboy" is the type of film I can say is good and pretty well-made, but I wouldn't watch it again.  It's a very unpleasant film to sit through.  It involves two characters who are at the bottom of the barrel of society.  I think Schlesinger did the best he could with this kind of subject matter.  The acting is very good.  Jon Voight does a superb job and so does Dustin Hoffman, though I wouldn't regard this as his best performance.  Dustin's one of my favorite actors, but when I think of him "Rainman" comes to mind. I don't think he could've played the role any better, but I don't consider it a memorable role.  The flashbacks and dream sequences are quite pretentious, and get annoying and confusing at times.  I guess 1969 was a time when directors were experimenting with all sorts of fancy-schmancy cinematic tools that they couldn't use back in the day.  And I'm pretty sure the nudity and sexual content was considered shocking back then.  Watching this movie in contemporary times, the explicit nudity and sex in this movie doesn't shock me one bit.  This is basically a character study.  There's no solid storyline here.  The characters are realistic and well-written, but it's hard to engage yourself in their scummy environment.  Nevertheless, they are somewhat likable and I did find the ending very sad.  This is also a movie that exemplifies the power of friendship--a subject that many movies tend to overlook. Especially if it's between two guys.  Nowadays you see a lot of movies about female bonding, but if you make a movie about two guys who love and care for each other it would be considered "gay."  I wish people can be more mature and make more films about the power of friendship, whether it's between males or females.  And of course, no one can forget the title song "Everybody's Talkin'."  Ever since I watched the movie yesterday, I couldn't flush this song out of my head.  It's such a great song."Midnight Cowboy" is a good, but unpleasant and deeply disturbing film that I would recommend.  But if you're like me, you would probably stick to seeing it once.  My score:  7 (out of 10)

I saw this in the theater during it's initial release and have seen it on TV many, many times since and it still remains one of my favorites. What an accomplishment this film achieved with it's Best Picture, Best Director and Best Screenplay Academy Award wins for 1969. It had seven deserved nominations. Look back at the films nominated or considered for the films of 1969 at the Academy awards; Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, Easy Rider, The Wild Bunch, Paint Your Wagon, Bob & Carol & Ted & Alcie, Goodbye Columbus, True Grit, Anne of a Thousand Days, The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie, Cactus Flower, Hello Dolly, Z, They Shoot Horse Don't They and The Sterile Cukoo among them. For this to get Best Picture and Best Director as an X-rated movie as it was originally rated then which later became an R and to win that and be so recognized out of some great memorable films for that year is quite a statement. A great cast with great chemistry between the Principal actors in Dustin Hoffman and John Voight with wonderful support from Sylvia Miles, John McGiver, Brenda Vacaro, Barnard Hughes and Ruth White. A lot of movies departed from your typical Hollywood feature around this time and this helped lead the way and abandoned the Hollywood Movie for American Cinema. Director John Schlesinger deserves a lot of credit for putting this out and making such a remarkable picture. Great music in this flick too. I would give this a 10 on a scale of 10 and highly recommend it.

A quarter century before "Brokeback Mountain" was acclaimed as a great gay love story, John Schlesinger's "Midnight Cowboy" had already broken the same ground, although in a subtler manner. Anyone who misted up at the sight of Jack's denim jacket within Ennis's shirt will certainly be moved by the ending of "Midnight Cowboy." Joe Buck and Ratso Rizzo are not as ideally coupled as Ennis and Jack, although all four men considered themselves to be straight, and at least three of them had sexual relations with women. Joe Buck is a self-styled stud from Texas, who arrives in New York City intent on making his fortune by servicing the sex-starved ladies of Manhattan. Enter Ratso Rizzo, a lame, sick con man, who scratches out an existence on the fringes of society. After an initial swindle, Ratso senses an opportunity in the naive young Joe. He offers Joe shelter in his rooms within an abandoned building after the Texan has run through his meager funds. Joe and Ratso make an "Oscar and Felix" odd couple. However, a bond grows between the two men as the roles shift from Ratso's seeking to help Joe establish himself as a hustler to Joe's becoming the protector and provider for a seriously ill Ratso.While there is no implicit or implied sexual relationship between the two men, only the purposely blind could fail to see that love grows between them as Ratso becomes increasingly dependent on Joe and Joe assumes a care-giving role. However, the sexual orientation of Joe Buck is ambiguous. While he has bedded his girlfriend in Texas and a couple of women in New York, he also allowed a young male student to perform a sex act on him in a theater and went back to the hotel room of an older man with the apparent knowledge of the man's intentions. Although ostensibly imitating Paul Newman's image in "Hud," Joe's cowboy attire, which is complete with boots, fringe, and stetson, are iconic gay apparel, and Ratso tells him so. Ratso's orientation is also ambiguous, and his sexual virginity was made clear. Thus, there is no barrier to assuming that Joe and Ratso had feelings for each other that were similar to those between Ennis and Jack.Schlesinger set his love story against the flash and grime of 60's New York, and his visual style is replete with flashbacks, quick cuts, and black-and-white scenes. Although the film basically follows Joe's adventures in the big city and his relationship with Ratso, there is not a dull moment, and, like "Taxi Driver," "Midnight Cowboy" is a time-capsule look at the pimps, drug culture, and sleaze of 42nd Street during the pre-Giuliani days. Surrounded by colorful supporting performances from Sylvia Miles, Brenda Vaccaro, Barnard Hughes, and John McGiver, Jon Voight as Joe Buck and Dustin Hoffman as Ratso Rizzo have arguably never been better. Add Fred Neil's song "Everybody's Talking' at Me," Adam Holender's cinematography, and Hugh Robertson's editing, and "Midnight Cowboy" is a classic love story between two unlikely individuals who both happen to be men.

It's an uncomfortable chore but if you can make it through Midnight Cowboy you shouldn't regret it. It is an excellent classic film that became the first X rated film to ever win best picture at the Academy Awards. And deservedly so. It follows the story of Joe Buck, a man from Texas who moves to New York to sell himself as a male prostitute. He slowly befriends the sickly and feeble Ratso who, for a time, acts as his "manager" if that's what you want to call it. It's a harrowing struggle for survival on the fast moving urban streets of New York, and Joe and Ratso learn this the hard way as they struggle to make money and find themselves in all sorts of tight spots, some profane and others euphoric. Whatever preconceptions you have about a film called Midnight Cowboy are probably wrong and you really just have to see this film for yourself to understand what its all about.Midnight Cowboy can be an uncomfortable film to watch but, to me at least, that makes it all the more memorable. It takes a lot of risks with its sexual content, especially for a film made in 1969. But it is all in good taste and all used to artistic effect. The film utilizes a great combination of aesthetics and storyline. I was very surprised at the visual quality of this film and all the aesthetic nuances it uses throughout. The film is very surreal at times and will take you on a very strange and enigmatic mind trip. Scenes will, practically without warning, morph into surreal acid trips that will stun and mystify. John Schlesinger really put forth a lot of effort to piece together meticulous scenes of surreal beauty and keep them appropriate within the context of the film. A lot of these bizarre scenes caught me off guard but made for some of the most visually fascinating moments of the whole film.The film isn't all aesthetic glam however. It is fueled primarily by a very strong story with two captivating main characters. The film will mislead you into thinking it will be a straightforward archetypal western, but then becomes a harrowing urban drama. It tells a dark but unique story that doesn't unfold like you would expect. And the story is powered by two very different but very well constructed characters. They are both multi-layered and well rounded. Both have their flaws but both elicit empathy, from me at least. And of course Jon Voight and Dustin Hoffman do a great job in their roles as well. Jon Voight warps the perception of the cowboy hero in the most unorthodox and unconventional ways. He isn't necessarily set up as an anti-hero but instead just misguided. His moral compass is very off, and yet you can only really feel sorry for him and his naivety. Dustin Hoffman's performance as Ratso is alright, but it is undoubtedly dedicated and sincere. The ability of his acting may not be top notch in this film, but it is very apparent that he put his heart and soul into this performance and was, for the most part, believable.Midnight Cowboy isn't your average film, and that is what makes it such a classic. It intricately combines visual flare and a three dimensional storyline to make it a unique experience that encompasses what good filmmaking is all about. It's bizarre transitions from real to surreal make it an enticing watch. It is a very high quality film that can't easily be forgotten.

Review title: A brutal depiction of broken dreams and lives asunder in the fetid backwash of the swinging Sixties.
Review_body: A dim-witted Texan (Jon Voight) comes to New York to offer his services as a stud for rich women, but to his distaste is forced by economic hardship to service gay men too. He falls in with a tubercular con artist (Dustin Hoffman), and they form an unlikely friendship.Midnight Cowboy is an unblinking gaze at Manhattan's seedy side, where harshness can co-exist with surprising tenderness. At the time, the film looked like a stern response to the consequence-free ethos of drop-out culture. Hoffman and Voight, two very different actors playing contrasting characters, constitute a dream team; by its end, this harrowing account feels more like a rites-of-passage story. The film won three Academy Awards: Best Picture, Best Director and Best Adapted Screenplay.

I love movies like 1969's Midnight Cowboy. They are the kind of movies that are embedded in American culture. They tell a story about the reality of everyday people and the themes explored are ones that people can relate to. I love all different kind of stories, but I find these stories featuring real-life themes to be more meaningful. This is a classic example of an American film-a film with a gritty tone involving the everyday life of ordinary people. The Hollywood studio system began to change in the late 1960's and instead of focusing on big-budget epics, they narrowed their focus down to American dramas similar in style to this film. The 1970's is very popular regarding these kind of films, so stay tuned for future reviews to understand my point.The main theme of the movie is love. But it's not just any kind of love. The movie has overtones of homosexuality, which caused lots of controversy when released. It was unheard of that a movie would feature such things in a movie, but as Bob Dylan likes to sing, "times are a-changing." The love interests are between our two main characters, a Texas cowboy named Joe Buck and a New York City outcast named Ratso. At first, they only use each other for business interests. But as the movie progress, a friendship evolves between them. A very close friendship that symbolizes something deeper than that. The movie does not explicitly say the men were gay (although there are some scenes that may say otherwise), but it grows clearer and clearer there is some kind of romantic attraction between the two men. Here is some interesting trivia. When it came out, it received an X-rating. This is the only motion picture to have ever been nominated for Best Picture at the Oscars with an X-rating. People felt like the film would give their children very bad influences, which I believe was a bunch of crap. However in 1972, the film was changed to an R-rating where it currently stands today.This film is essentially a love story set in the good ol' Big Apple. Joe Buck (Jon Voight) is a hustler who is from Texas. He decides to move to New York City to chase his big dream involving lots of cash and women. But very quickly he learns the city in the east is a much different animal compared to his small Texas hometown. He makes some money as a hustler, but he doesn't have very many opportunities. Then he meets a shady man named Ratso (Dustin Hoffman) who deals with the underbelly of New York. They forge a partnership as Ratso decides to show Joe Buck how to make it rich. As the adventures begin to roll on, they might have feelings for each other that they could have never expected to have.These kind of films rely on acting, and it's an understatement to say Hoffman and Voight crushed it with their roles. Hoffman was a rising star with his turn in 1967's The Graduate, but he shows here that film was no fluke. Hoffman's character was not a guy I'd generally root for, but Hoffman gave his character so much sympathy. He was a flawed man who needed a friend and more importantly, needed love. I find it ironic how the character's name was Ratso. Ratso did somewhat resemble a human-sized rat in the movie, which I guess is a symbol for the criminal underbelly of New York City. Jon Voight crushes it in one of his first major roles. The scenes when he first arrives in New York are fabulous and pretty funny. His cowboy hat doesn't look right amongst the clad of people in their business suits and I love how he tried to hustle women in public to no avail. New York is a different beast, my friend. The chemistry between the two are spot-on. From their mutual thoughts on living in Florida to their hustling deals, the chemistry here is something special.The film relies upon the dynamite performances of Hoffman and Voight to succeed, but there is the tidy direction of John Schlesinger who helped changed the face of cinema with his controversial art. There is the strong screenplay Waldo Scott, which depicts the underbelly of American life in a way that it makes it difficult to watch. I only wished he left out that stupid psychedelic party scene of his screenplay. It really did not fit with the tone of the movie and it was cringing to watch, although this is where we can see love come into play for the two characters. This era also introduced using songs in addition to the score. The Graduate began that trend, and the film makes good example from that trend. The song, "Everybody's Talking' to Me" is a wonderful song with strong lyrics that add to the story.Midnight Cowboy is an American film that is known as a love story between bros, but it is deeper than that. It's a story about valued friendship. The paths are very different at the end, compared to where they were in the beginning. The ending comes across as tragic, but in a way it is also a very sweet ending. I had misty eyes, but I also had a nice smile on my face. Honestly, there shouldn't have been any controversy with the film. If this was released today, people wouldn't bat an eye at the subject matter. Luckily, the majority of the people loved this film upon release and it became a heavily influential film. Just see 2005's Brokeback Mountain, and you'll see some similar themes. I really enjoyed watching the movie. I was curious at why the film was deemed controversial, but in the end it was just another powerful love story.My Grade: A

A naive country boy and a timid New York con artist don't exactly conjure up the stereotypical image one has of friendships,but this is exactly what happens in Midnight Cowboy.The film illustrates that friendships can develop out of nowhere and between individuals that one would ever suspect would be friends in a million years.I had to overlook the surrealism,which I'm not really into,and the in your face sexual content which is unnecessary,but I like the basic story that it presents.Dustin Hoffman and Jon Voight do some awesome acting here,as always,and I was quite taken with Brenda Vaccarro,whom I didn't realize was so awesome looking in her youth.Good film.

Review title: As Long As I Live, I'll Never Forget This Film.
Review_body: Midnight Cowboy is a 1969 American drama film based on the 1965 novel of the same name by James Leo Herlihy. The script was written by Waldo Salt, directed by John Schlesinger, and stars Jon Voight in the title role alongside Dustin Hoffman. The film won three Academy Awards: Best Picture, Best Director and Best Adapted Screenplay. To date, it is the only X-rated film ever to win Best Picture. It has since been labeled as one of the greatest American movies of all time.The plot of the film deals with Joe Buck (Jon Voight), a young Texan who works as a dishwasher. As the film opens, Joe dresses in new cowboy clothing, packs a suitcase, and quits his job. He heads to New York City hoping to succeed as a male prostitute. Joe's naïveté is quickly evident. Initially unsuccessful, he succeeds in bedding a well-to-do middle-aged New Yorker (Sylvia Miles), but Joe ends up giving her money. Joe then meets Enrico "Ratso" Rizzo (Dustin Hoffman), a crippled, street con man who takes $20 from Joe by offering to introduce him to a known pimp, who turns out to be a Bible thumper (John McGiver). Joe flees the encounter in pursuit of Rizzo.Joe spends his days wandering the city and sitting in his hotel room. Soon broke, he is locked out of his hotel room and most of his belongings are confiscated. He tries to make money by agreeing to receive oral sex from a young man (Bob Balaban) in a movie theater. When Joe learns that he has no money, Joe threatens him. The following day, Joe spots Rizzo and angrily shakes him down. Rizzo offers to share his apartment in a condemned building. Joe accepts reluctantly, and they begin a "business relationship", hustling. The two loners develop a true bond. Rizzo's health, which has never been good, steadily worsens.Joe's story is told through flashbacks. His grandmother raises him after his mother abandons him, though his grandmother frequently neglects him as well. He and his girlfriend, Crazy Annie are raped, after drawing the ire of local townspeople. She is institutionalized, and Joe joins the army. Rizzo's back story comes through stories he tells Joe. His father was an illiterate Italian immigrant shoe-shiner who worked down in a subway station, developed a bad back, and "coughed his lungs out from breathin' in that wax all day". Rizzo learned shining from his father but wont stoop to it. He dreams of moving one day to Miami.An unusual couple approach Joe and Ratso in a diner and hand Joe a flyer, inviting him to a party. They enter a Warhol-esque party scene (with Warhol superstars in cameos). Naive Joe smokes a joint, thinking it's a cigarette, and, after taking a pill someone offered, begins to hallucinate. He leaves the party with a socialite (Brenda Vaccaro), who agrees to pay $20 for spending the night with her, but Joe cannot perform. They play Scribbage together, and Joe shows his limited academic prowess. She teasingly suggests that Joe may be gay, and he is suddenly able to perform. The two enjoy lively, aggressive sex. In the morning, the socialite sets up her friend as Joe's next customer, and it appears that his career is on its way.When Joe returns home, Rizzo is bedridden and feverish. Rizzo refuses medical help and begs Joe to put him on a bus to Florida. Desperate, Joe picks up a man in a gay bar (Barnard Hughes), and when things go wrong, robs the man when he tries to pay with a religious medallion, instead of cash. With the cash, Joe buys bus tickets. On the journey, Rizzo's frail physical condition further deteriorates. At a rest stop, Joe buys new clothing for Rizzo and himself, discarding his cowboy outfit. As they near Miami, Joe talks of getting a regular job, only to realize Rizzo has died. The driver tells Joe there is nothing else to do but continue on to Miami. The film closes with Joe seated with his arm around his dead friend.The chemistry between Jon Voight and Dustin Hoffman is why this film works. Jon Voight plays his role to perfection. His dreams of making it big are foiled at every step of his adventure. In the end he gives up and is back to where he began. The loss of his good friend Rizzo will weigh very heavily on his soul. This film was rated X, but there is nothing here than than the occasional bare butt and breasts shown. In fact today's film show more trashy scenes than this film. For persons seeking to make a career as a male escort, this is a film you should see before you embark on your adventure.

Review title: A simple story with complex characters
Review_body: -Spoilers Within-`Midnight Cowboy' was nothing like I expected.  Generally, when you watch a movie where the plot is essentially a train wreck waiting to happen, there is a low point, a high point and then a REALLY low point.  `Midnight Cowboy', the story of a cocksure and (briefly) idealistic and naïve hustler from Texas who moves to New York City to make his fortune doesn't have a high point.  Indeed, I found myself actually wanting Joe Buck (Voight) and Ratso Rizzo (Hoffman) to have that brief moment where they actually succeed in promoting and selling Buck's `services' to women (or men), but that moment just doesn't come  this is a film that is brutally real, and anything but glamorous.  The characters of Buck and Rizzo are complex without being heavy-handed, and their portrayal is inspired.  At times the film turned pretty psychedelic, but it was a product of 1969, so it is forgivable.  I found that it was impossible to turn away from the film, even for a minute because Schlesinger's pace and direction are absolutely compelling.  This is certainly not a film to watch when you're trying to get a `pick me up', but it is an important one because it is a fine example of the realism that pervaded cinema in the late Sixties/early Seventies after the largely idealistic and/or melodramatic Fifties.--Shelly

Review title: Glass half full movie that has aged.
Review_body: I am struggling to be positive about this film that somehow won the 1969 Best Picture, Director (Brit John Schlesinger) and screenplay.Perhaps best known for the sing "Everybody's Talking' at Me' sung by Harry Nilsson. The film stars Jon Voight as a Texan dishwasher Joe Buck. The film begins with Buck starting a new life in New York City as a hustler hoping to earn money as a Texan stud for sex. Being not very successful he meets a streetwise con man Enrico "Ratso" Rizzo (Dustin Hoffman). Ratso is not in the best of physical health and has fantasies of a new life in Miami, Florida. Meanwhile Buck has flashbacks of a shocking sexual assault on himself and his his girlfriend.The pair struggle by in their squat until towards the end of the film where the pair take a 31 hour bus journey to a Miami (presumably far cheaper than air travel, and it's 1969?) I found the film depressing and through periods boring. I don't know what the other films were at those Academy Awards. Perhaps some of the subject matter was a bit X rated at the time but by modern standards is rather tame.

Review title: The underbelly of the American experience
Review_body: Midnight Cowboy is an insightful exposé into the unseemly underbelly of the American experience. Thankfully most of us will never have to experience what it is like to be left behind as one of the castoffs unable to enjoy the finer things in life as we wallow in filth and degeneracy desperately looking for some temporary escape. Jon Voigt and Dustin Hoffman deserved their Oscar nominations for playing the dull-witted would-be gigolo and the greasy small-time con man respectively. I appreciated the narrative, the acting, and the technical competence of the film, though I have no desire to ever visit these two godless characters again, 8/10.

People going from rural areas to the big towns are normally coming with a lot of dreams of success, and this was the case of a young good-looking man Joe Buck (Jon Voight) who supposed he could have succeeded in New York easily because of his tall athletic figure as a kind of a new gigolo. Life showed him that success in the Big Apple is an issue. This was what he learned from his new friend the sick young man Enrico Salvatore (Dustin Hoffman), also known as Ratzo. The latter lived in conditions similar to the ones common to rats, no hygiene, no food, simply surviving. The worst came in the evening during winter time, no heating at all, due to this fact Ratzo had tuberculosis. What a nightmare in a town thought by many as the best of the world! The director John Schlesinger was able to show that the appearances do not always show the true aspects of a town or a country. Ratzo was the example, he was not a bad man but he had to fight, to steal and to do whatever possible to survive, and at the same time he was Joe's teacher. Ratzo was able to persuade Joe to go to Florida looking for a more benign weather, Joe got the money serving as a gigolo for an old homosexual man, they made it, but Ratzo died. This excellent film is a lesson not only to Joe but to many people trying to emigrate to New York, where you may succeed or you may die. The film should be among the 100 best of all times.

Review title: Funny and depressing. Bleak and hopeful. High and low.
Review_body: Midnight Cowboy is a bizarre, hodgepodge, paradoxical masterpiece of both mainstream and avant- grade cinema. After all what other film that was then rated X (though this was eventually changed to an R) has ever won the Academy Award for Best Picture? Joe Buck (Jon Voight) is a young Texas man who heads to New York City in the hopes of becoming a hustler (in this case a gigolo by choice). He meets ailing thief and fellow hustler Rico Rizzo (Dustin Hoffman) with whom he forms a bond as the two decide to help each other with their plans. Rizzo wants to set Joe up with women so the two can go to Miami, Florida. We oddly root for the two in spite of neither of them being particularly admirable. Moreover Joe and Rizzo live largely on the edge of society. Joe loses his luggage after he is unable to pay for his hotel room any further and is left without options until he finds Rizzo again and the two live in a squatted apartment in a condemned building. The images of high and low society are juxtaposed in montage and surreal fantasy/flashback sequences. Such a film easily could have gone poorly but Midnight Cowboy doesn't really. It never felt like any of the unconventional elements went too far, as this is still a film with a plot as opposed to pure art house. Not a type of experience I've seen replicated in many other films; Midnight Cowboy comes recommended.

Well, I saw this film for the first time just the other day, and I was left with mixed reactions.  It was good, but I don't understand why this is regarded as a classic.  Solid performances by Voight and Hoffman are almost wasted by a number of irritating flashbacks and the occasional worthless scene that helped to pad an already bloated running time.  With all that said, I did enjoy the film.  Besides the good acting, I did end up liking these characters, which made the ending all the more effective.  This is a mixed review to be sure, but I still think that it's worth checking out.

Review title: Two Unforgettable losers that make a magnificent movie!
Review_body: The best way I can put this movie is a story about two losers. John Voight is Joe Buck, a naïve, handsome young man who decides that he wants more in life than just working at a burger joint. With his cowboy outfit and radio, he heads off to the Big Apple to find his fortune. There he meets Ratso (Dustin Hoffman) a sleazy con artist who also his looking for some money. After Ratso cons Joe out of twenty dollars, they become unlikely friends and develop a unique relationship.Last year, AFI ranked Midnight Cowboy among the top 100 list of America's best films. Some people that I have met contradict this movie as dull and depressing. It is a very depressing movie, for it depicts the slum of New York City's streets of the 1960s. The characters themselves are depressed by their passed and current demons. But I also understand why AFI ranks this as one of America's best movies. Despite the con artists, male and female prostitutes, and nut jobs, there is room for hope and a friendship.I have seen both actors in many different movies and seeing them together on screen is captivating. Both were nominated for the Best Actor award of 1970 but unfortunately neither of them got it. This may have been because of John Wayne (the winner of that year for True Grit) was coming of age and needed an award for something. Nonetheless, their performances are impeccable. I could easily feel for their characters.The film was also excellent in the work of the director John Schlesinger who brought to life the Gomorrah attitude of New York City. The one scene that I felt was extremely well done by the director was the sequence of where Joe and Ratso go to a party that is made up of crazies, drugs, and sex. The camera angles and the styles of editing and color made everything unusual, as if the characters were on drugs, which they were.Overall, I can't say anything bad about this movie. 10/10

This a feel-bad movie. Don't watch it if you're looking for any kind of positive emotions, because there are none in this movie. It's constant sadness, suffering and hopelessness, and it's only made bearable by Joe Buck's naive optimism, which also kinda makes it hurt even more.It's also a must-watch. Jon Voight and Dustin Hoffman give truly magnificent performances and the film goes into unexpect psychedelic places. Hoffman's peformance in particular as a sick man who's condition slowly deteriorates over the course of the movie is so believable that I felt like I got a fever just from watching him.

The performances from Jon Voight and Dustin Hoffman are reason enough to watch this film. They make their characters seem very real. This is a great film, but it is also a very sad one. The film shows us a side of the world we don't usually see, and it's a tough life for these two street hustlers. There are some true heart-breaking moments in this one. Strong film.

Review title: One of those greatest classics severely underrated, and with a somber ending
Review_body: I didn't at all think of it this way, but my friend said the first thing he thought when he heard the title "Midnight Cowboy" was a gay porno. At that point, all I had known of it was the reference made to it in that "Seinfeld" episode with Jerry trying to get Kramer to Florida on that bus and Kramer's all sick and with a nosebleed.The movie was great, and surprisingly upbeat and not all pissy pretentious pessimistic like some movies I can't even remember because they're all crap.The plot basically consisted of a naive young cowboy Joe Buck going to New York trying to be a hustler (a male prostitute, basically), thinking it'll be easy pickings, only to hit the brick wall hard when a woman ends up hustling HIM, charging him for their sexual encounter.Then he meets Enrico Salvatore Rizzo, called "Ratso" by everyone and the cute gay guys who make fun of him all the time. You think of him as a scoundrel, but a lovable one (like Han Solo or Lando Calrissian) and surprisingly he and Joe become friends, and the movie is so sweet and heartwarming watching them being friendlier and such and such. Rizzo reveals himself to actually be a sad, pitiable man who's very sick, and very depressed and self-conscious, hates being called "Ratso" and wants to go to Florida, where he thinks life will be much better and all his problems resolved, and he'll learn to be a cook and be famous there.It's heartwarming watching Joe do all that he does to get them both down to Florida, along with many hilarious moments (like Ratso trying to steal food at that hippie party, and getting caught by the woman who says "Gee, well, you know, it's free. You don't have to steal it." and he says "Well if it's free then I ain't stealin' it", and that classic moment completely unscripted and unscheduled where Hoffman almost gets hit by that Taxi, and screams "Hey, I'm walkin' here! I'm walkin' here!"), and the acting is so believable, you'd never believe Joe Buck would grow up to be the distinguished and respected actor Jon Voight, and Ratso Rizzo would grow up to be the legendary and beloved Dustin Hoffman. It's not the first time they've worked together in lead roles, but the chemistry is so thick and intense.Then there's the sad part that I believe is quite an overstatement to call it "depressing". Ratso Rizzo is falling apart all throughout the movie, can barely walk, barely eat, coughs a lot, is sick, and reaches a head-point on the bus on its way to Florida. He's hurting badly, and only miles away from Miami, he finally dies on the bus. The bus driver reassures everyone that nothing's wrong, and continues on. Sad, but not in the kind of way that'd make you go home and cry and mope around miserably as though you've just lost your dog of 13 years.All in all, great movie. And the soundtrack pretty much consists just of "Everybody's Talking'" played all throughout the movie at appropriate times. An odd move, but a great one, as the song is good and fits in with the tone of the movie perfectly. Go see it, it's great, go buy it

Review title: Two lonely men in New York city 6/10
Review_body: The story of a amarican gigolo who leaves Texas to New York in hopes of becoming a big shot. Turns into a self discovery quest along with a bizarre friend. Dustin Hoffman and Jon Voight are great actors and their interactions through the film are rush, difficult and supporting. Voight's character Joe Buck is naive and full of childhood dramas. Hoffman's character ratso is well aware of the poverty and scum in New York, he is adapted to this life while Joe Buck is lost in the big city. What mostly surprised me was how negative movies about New York in the 60's - 70's were directed. While Woody Allen's movies about New York were mostly positive and wonderful. If you take "Midnight Cowboy" and "Manhattan" for instance and compare them to each other you'll see that they are nothing alike even if they take place in the same years and location. By tone, view, characters and light, these movies are completely different. I like to see both sides of New York presented in movies: both positive and negative sides.

Midnight Cowboy is #36 on the American Film Institute's 100 best films and it won three Oscars including Best Picture in 1969. It was also rated X (NC17 nowadays) although today it's equivalent to a weak R which shows how much movie morals have changed in 35 years. You should see this movie for the acting of Dustin Hoffman as Ratso Rizzo and Jon Voight as Joe Buck. Ratso is a ragged New York street urchin and Joe Buck is a young plastic cowboy from Texas. Joe gets the idea that he'll go to New York and make a living as a stud off all the rich women in Manhattan. Ratso is a sickly street con-man who tricks Joe and then runs into him later. They begin an unlikely partnership. This movie is about friendship and redemption. There's no mistaking that it's a real downer film but it does make its point. Joe's journey through the underbelly of New York spirals into hell as he turns over one rock after another, each one hiding a bigger pervert. There is Towney the traveling salesman, John McGiver as the preacher in a squalid hotel room, Bob Balaban as a teen homosexual. Parts of the film are definitely dated such as the drug laden, swinging Greenwich Village party scene but it does show that aspect of 60s culture. In my opinion, Hoffman and Voight never equaled their roles in this film and Ratso and Joe are two of the most unforgettable characters in film history. Be prepared to be depressed, but see this film.

Review title: A Timeless Celebration of Futile Optimism
Review_body: A simplistic but mostly naive young man from Texas, Joe Buck, ironically becomes a cowboy after deciding to leave his hometown, headed to the last place that that kind of legendary hero exists, New York City, as every frame of MIDNIGHT COWBOY means something: starting from a sunlit drive-in to a public shower where Joe drops the soap...An obvious nod for an inevitable detour within a disturbing, almost sadistic character-driven story that's bright and cheerful otherwise, but that's when centered narrowly on Jon Voight's title character, who shows enough humanity and vulnerability in what he's hiding as first-billed sidekick Dustin Hoffman's crippled con-man hustler, Ratso Rizzo, appears to be right upfront: a tattered and swarthy, street savvy con-man who walks in a permanent, unguided shuffle that, alongside the handsome, tall blond Texan, make for perhaps the most bizarre odd couple of top-grade exploitation cinema: in one of the most well-deserved films to win Best Director (for John Schlesinger) and Best Picture (although another movie cowboy would take the Best Actor)...Curbing a seemingly endless gust of serious and often painstaking hard luck roadblocks are genuinely funny moments centered on and around the unlikely duo, teamed-up after what feels like fully-conceived short films...Including the initial bus trip; a clumsy attempt at hustling; and the doomed yet determined partnership before a sharp, frostbit winter cuts into Ratso's idyllic reverie of sunny Florida while the desperate, starving creature of a bleak and mysterious New York City (even haunting under a heavy dose of psychedelia) formidably reigns. By the end, what the audience has experienced, and the characters suffered through, can't reach the unique form of dark, tangible reality that no fiction (on screen or print) has yet to challenge, or equal.

Stars magnificent in eliciting our sympathy. 
Wished treatment of gay characters was more sympathetic and we saw more of New York's underbelly, besides Ratso's squat. 
Some aspects of direction haven't aged well.

Review title: The most annoying movie of all time!!!
Review_body: This film had a really bad effect on me.  First of all, the story is completely improbable and dated, and second of all, there is not one likeable character in this stupid film.  I mean its bad enough seeing Jon Voight strutin around town like a horny schoolboy, set to that awful theme song.  Let's see, the worst moment?, must have been the scene were John Voight and Dustin Hoffman were hopping around to "Orange Juice On Ice".  A really awful film, full of dull characters and writing.  The is probubly Hoffman's worst film up until Ishtar(1987), and Im still thinking that might have even been better!!  My rating: *1/2 out of ****.

Review title: Stud Joe Buck -- virile and naive, just how I like 'em.
Review_body: Just kidding.Seeking greener pastures in the form of hustling in New York City, Jon Voight is young optimist Cowboy (almost Forest Gump-like) Joe Buck from Texas. It does not take long for the Big Apple to mercilessly swallow him and his ambitions whole and very soon Joe is the target of both the coldness of New Yorkers and cons from its street-thugs. Given his pure heart, he takes pity on one of these thugs, Ratso Rizzo (Dustin Hoffman) and later moves in with him in his wreck of apartment and the two literally struggle to survive.While Midnight Comedy is labeled as a drama, it is best described as either a tragic comedy or a comedic tragedy in my opinion. It is above all a beautiful film that is stylish in capturing the contemporary hippie-vibe of the late 1960s with its mandatory dizzying Warhol-party cinematography and juxtaposing it with ultra-urban New York City. The film crams Cowboy Joe Buck somewhere in between, thereby emphasizing his out-of-place position. We feel for his struggle to fit in, but also to merely get enough money to feed Ratso Rizzo.Midnight Cowboy brought tears to my eyes as it is also rich in substance and projects a lot of heart. I imagine this film must have inspired both Forest Gump with its pure-hearted and out-of-place lead character and, to an extent, the Crocodile Dundee films as it deals with almost the exact same kind of humour - a contrast between country-cowboys and slick New York cosmopolitans. Very compelling and sensationally creative film that I highly recommend.8.5/10

A very stylized movie, with a constant stream of flashbacks and imagery as we follow a young man trying to make his way in New York. The pictures and scenes of New York are fantastic but will eventually change. The friendship between the two leads Dustin Hoffman and Jon Voight is the odd relationship but becomes the emotional punch as they both try and survive.

Review title: Welcome to the infernal streets of NYC
Review_body: "Midnight Cowboy" is a 1969 drama directed by John Schlesinger starring Jon Voight and Dustin Hoffman. I think I don't really need to explain my endless love for older films, especially the ones from the sixties. It was the era of groundbreaking filmmaking and most titles that hit the big screen during that time are still guide posts for the modern cinema of today, may it be the infamously scandalous drama "The Graduate", subtle horror gem "Rosemary's Baby" or action thriller "Bullitt". All of them contributed something to their time and that's what makes them stand out even as of today. This drama here also has a particular feature that changed cinema forever, as it was firstly given the famous X-rating for the delicate topics it deals with. That's what had my curiosity in the first place and when Amazon had this title on sale, I just couldn't resist. As expected, I wasn't disappointed in the slightest. The film is composed of so many facets that you need to feel in the smallest detail to fully comprehend it. First of all, it's amazing how the film establishes two true antiheroes as the protagonists that you would avoid in reality but that you root for in this fictional context. I mean, one is a naïve and pompous misogynist and hustler who has not the faintest idea of how the world really works and the other is a greasy crook and thief with nothing but bad intentions in all his actions. Yet, the film makes you feel sympathy for them, as well as it let's you more and more comprehend their strangely damaged worldview. They both are the key figures in a story that obviously criticises the American dream. The extraordinary thing about it is that it doesn't rely on the lovely visuals of the sunny California, but rather builds up the nightmare in the nasty streets of New York City. It's a welcome alternation to all the Los Angeles based dramas and stands out with the dark and moody visuals. In the same manner it shatters all of Joe Buck's hopes of how his life in one of the greatest cities on the east coast would go on. Piece by piece, his dreams fall apart and it's all about surviving in the end. Luckily, he isn't alone in this misery, as he has one of the worst best friends in the world on his side. As if Voight's performance wasn't already mesmerizing, Hoffman once again has proven why he's one of the greatest actors of all time. His portrayal of Enrico "Ratso" Rizzo ist truly devastating and absolutely impressive all the same, he dominated every scene he's in and sent shivers down my spine, but at the same time doesn't overshadow his equally magnificent costar. It's their unlikely bond, their strange friendship that makes this film so fascinating. Most of this works out so well due to the exceedingly genuine chemistry between them. You really believe them and their shared pains and struggles, it's definitely gut wrenching at times. Even though I think that it could have gone deeper into the past of it's obviously troubled main character, the hypnotising editing style makes up for the missing elaboration of that very past. Now that I reconsider it, it's even more haunting to not know everything about it and makes these nightmarish imagery even more packing. Furthermore, the movie doesn't only send its leads on an infernal journey through the urban canyons of NYC, it also doesn't hesitate to blatantly criticise the American way of life, the extreme consumerism and the indifference of people towards misery, pain and neglect and even openly approaches homosexuality, except from the latter, which endearingly tantalises the emotions, it's these thematic insights that impacted me most and made my stomach ache from the intensity they produced. Only take a look at Rizzo's day dream of an easier life and the comparison of his wishful thinking with the bitterness of his very own reality. Already this scene solely is absolutely devastating and made me incredibly sad. It's uncompromising drama with enough moments of subtle satire and social criticism. I think it's not only the depressing themes and explicit nudity that granted it an X-rating, I think it's also been kind of a prevention measure to keep as many people as possible from witnessing how reality actually looks like. In our society today we're always up to date with all the nasty things in the world, but remember this was the sixties. It must have been a scandalous revelation to many audience members back in the day. The peak of all this is definitely the devastating death of Rizzo in the final minutes of the film. It's as unspectacular as it is not depressing, just notice the reactions of the other passengers of the bus. The quintessence of it is the unconcerned reaction of this one lady that barely takes notice of it and does her make up instead. A film doesn't have to be graphic to be brutal, this scene especially has shown it. In the end, Joe has learned from his recklessness and fatuity, but at what price? The film's obviously stating that people don't care about other people, especially the ones from another social class. It's mercilessly shown that they don't even care if you die. It's this nihilist world view that's as breathtaking as it's bold. All in all, this outstanding drama connects all the right pieces to a devastating puzzle about the failure of the American dream and the recklessness of the American way of life. It has it all, mesmerizing performances and a devastatingly touching story that make it work. It's a nasty, dirty and unexpectedly dark social satire that knows to make you feel uncomfortable at the right spots. You can't escape the undertow of lugubriousness of this quintessential sixties classic and groundbreaking feature of the New Hollywood. It's just too impressive.

Here we have an oscar winning film thats quite beloved but upon watching it I wasnt too hot on it and found it relatively mediocre. Jon Voight is Joe Buck (not to be mistaken for Fox NFL and MLB announcer) from Texas travelling to New York who hustles for women who he'll lay with and steal from. He builds a friendship with Ratso (Dustin Hoffman) who is a scruffy down on his luck conman. The relationship they build is pretty cool and the acting is pretty good but the story just wasnt all that interesting

Review title: A groundbreaking film that could have been better
Review_body: I've watched several movies from the 1960s and 70s recently and am surprised dismayed at how slow they now seem. In "Midnight Cowboy," Joe Buck (Jon Voight) doesn't get to New York until about 13:29 into the film and even then nothing much happens for several more minutes after he arrives.After viewing the film again, now that I am much older but not much wiser, and having read several reviews and articles about the production, I haven't the faintest notion of what the film is about. I must agree with Roger Ebert's conclusion that the film presents strong performances and enough material to whet the appetite, but fails to live up to its promise and potential.Schlesinger and Salt seem as if they couldn't decide whether they want to tell Joe Buck's story or their own, so cluttered the movie with scenes and images that have nothing to do with Joe Buck, but were strong personal impressions, such as the Warhol-esque party that British directors attend but are off limits to the unwashed masses, and images of New York shot from the wrong angle.Here's my tongue-in-cheek, cynical synopsis: A simpleminded Texas hick's latent homosexual tendencies are awakened when the entire male population of his backwater town collectively decide they would rather gang-rape him than his beautiful buxom girlfriend. He tries to escape his budding homosexuality by dressing in the gayest outfits he can buy and going to New York to become the only straight hustler working 42nd Street. But like the traveller to Samarra, his homosexuality follows him and he finds bittersweet fulfillment in a bromance with a cynical asexual cripple whose physical disabilities mirror his own emotional dysfunction.The movie leaves a lot of questions unanswered. In his hotel room, Joe is shown writing a postcard to a co-worker who is shown receiving the card. But the movie shows several fantasy scenes for both Joe and Ratzo, so we can't be sure he actually sent it. In the next shot, Joe tears up a similar card and tosses the pieces out the window. Who was the intended recipient of the second card? His girlfriend Annie? What happened to Annie? As the police lead her away after the attack, she points to Joe and says, "He's the only one." Then she disappears from Joe's flashbacks. Personally, I like nonlinear stories and consider flashbacks a potent tool. And I like stories told from multiple perspectives, provided those perspectives are clearly delineated. But MC presents a jumble of memories and fantasies, some in B&W, others in Technicolor, for Joe, Ratso, Schlesinger, Salt and Holender.And yet the movie won three Academy Awards, including Best Picture, which everybody expected to go to "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid." Heller was so convinced the film would lose that he didn't even bother preparing an acceptance speech.I wonder if it won the award based on what it represented as much as what it accomplished. In 1969, the film industry was still hobbled not only by MPAA ratings but also by National Catholic Office for Motion Pictures ratings. (Curiously, the Catholics condemned "Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice" that year, but not "Midnight Cowboy." The vanguards of cinema were the French, Italians and Swedes. Perhaps the members of the Academy rallied around MC because it broke taboos, even though BCATSD was a better film and a more conventional bromance. After MC took the Oscar, MPAA changed the rating from X to R, demonstrating that their ratings are purely objective.

When I got the tape I was sure I had a good movie in my hands. It was easy to know how good it was when I saw the cast list and the director's name in the credits. "Midnight Cowboy" can't be considered the best movie in the world, but it is simply great, and this true. Dustin Hoffmann is very well in his character and John Voight really surprised me. I knew he is good, but not that good. John Schlesinger directs this film with talent and sensibility. It just can't be missed. My Rate 8/10

I hate giving movies a 10 because I always feel there might be an imperfection I missed. This movie was perfect. 2 totally different people that bonded and learned from each other. This is a movie about hopes, starting a new, reinventing yourself and living life to your fullest. Jon Voight was not a male prostitute but more of a hustler that did what he had to do to survive in NYC. Ditto Dustin Hoffman aka Ratso. This movie is timeless and interesting side note. This movie is only movie to be rated X to win best picture. Its hardly an x-rated movie and has since been re rated an R. My guess is that the raters being novices erred on the side of caution. Anyway an entertaining movie of male bonding . Fantastic movie and a segue-way for sure of more over the top , controversial movies that were a gateway to the 70s and beyond. Many of the lessons from this movie are timeless. Enough ranting just see the movie and judge for yourself.

I recently watched this flick after seeing a Decades TV show about Dustin Hoffman. Hoffman was just becoming famous in 1969 while I think Jon Voight was pretty unknown still. Ratso Rizzo (Hoffman) is a small time hustler of dubious means living in NYC. Joe Buck (Voight) is a small time dreamer from Texas who gets on a bus to make it big up north in NYC.Buck is a cowboy's cowboy, but he's not really a cowboy. He dresses up in shirts and hats and pants and boots, but he's all image. He wants to pass himself off to hustle women. He ends up with a lot more than he bargained for because he gets taken left and right by bigger hustlers after he gets to NYC. Rizzo ends up forming a loose friendship with him as they co-hustle small time deals left and right. Drugs, sex, and a little rock and roll punctuate their lives together. Rizzo dreams of leaving NYC it seems, dreaming of Florida of all places. They have an adventurous time in NYC and beyond.I felt the story fell somewhat flat in the final scenes. I kept wondering what the point was. It seemed that not a lot of substance was happening. They were stuck, which I guess was the point. When they deal with their own fates as life encircles them at the end, I felt that the Director tried to deliver a message that might have been better delivered. At that point, I thought maybe Joe Buck played too much of the cowboy character, and not enough of a real person. If he intends to change things, it would have helped make it more believable if his character didn't seem so clown-like at times.It was a good story, but depressing scenery of down and out NYC, with two losers trying to get their small pieces of the pie. Ratso, like a rat, trying to nibble every little bite he could out of life. Buck just riding the horse along for a good time, naive forever. Or is he? The story didn't give us enough to know.This film was worth watching for historical purposes. But I'm not sure it was worthy of Best Picture. Enjoy.

This runs like a documentary. Both actors are supurb. Hoffman really is very ill by the end of shooting. With a wonderful soundtrack and great scenes. When they are walking across the road, Dustin Hoffman really does nearly get run over by a New York Taxi driver who was unaware he was an actor or that they were filming!!

There's truly few moments in cinematic history when films can get so honest and substantial like Midnight Cowboy, which perfectly encapsulates New York City in the '60s, with its rawness, poverty and dispair. Two male strangers form a bond born out of their misery and willingness to overcome their existing problems and to make a living out of something, anything. They come from different worlds but come together to survive in a city that devours the unfortunate.There's a subtle hint at a homosexual attraction between the two, although not explored in the surface, it is still caught in the ambient and does nothing but to enrich the dynamic of their relationship. The city and its people are a wonderfully accurate depiction of New York's reality back in the day, much similar to Martin Scorsese's characterization of New York in Taxi Driver (1976) although much less grim in tone, in my opinion.
Jon Voight and Dustin Hoffman both shine in roles meant to feed off each other, not apart. Their dynamic is what brings this movie to life and that dynamic is accompanied and enhanced by brilliant camera work, outstanding direction and superb writing.Dustin Hoffman's famous line was a pure reaction to a cab driver almost running him over, which elevates the moment to a classic status forever
immortalized on film. Midnight Cowboy is an authentic product that packages technical brilliance, honest and heart-felt portrayals and an emotionally authentic display of true filmmaking. It's time you catch up with this unforgettable classic.

Review title: Hard Times, Friendship and Life Itself
Review_body: One of the most notable and lauded films in Hollywood history "Midnight Cowboy" is a compelling depiction of urban realist drama set in the colorful and turbulent 1960s. A charming and backward Texas cowboy travels to New York City to try his luck in the flesh trade and gets more than he bargained for. Along the slippery path he meets an equally down and out local and together they shoulder life's heavy burdens in one of the most affecting and memorable portrayals of friendship onscreen. Dustin Hoffman and Jon Voight are the central leads and their chemistry carry the film in all its rollercoaster motions. The film is also a nice glimpse into '60s New York and the Big Apple's concrete jungle is showcased in all its urban grime and sprawl with matching sex, drugs, good music and a psychedelic party with a Warhol cast to boot. The flick slows down in the middle but picks up again with a moving ending. A gem of art imitating life this is the kind of symbol and representation of an era that endures and stays with you.

Review title: A powerful, disturbing film driven by two magnificent performances
Review_body: Midnight Cowboy (1969)Number 1 - 1969Top 10 - 1960sMidnight Cowboy is in my opinion a very simple, yet important film. It follows the story of a naive Texas 'cowboy' who leaves his tightly knit community for the big, filthy, sleazy streets of 1960s New York (forget the clean shaven images of NYC today then it was in many ways a terrifying city) to become a male gigolo and make money from rich city ladies. However through a chain of events he runs out of money and he is not equipped enough to handle the bustling streets of NYC. The story evolves as Joe befriends Rico a crippled third-rate pickpocket and they form a bond as they try to survive.Firstly, Jon Voight (Joe) and Dustin Hoffman (Rico) are outstanding in the roles and we get two mature, intensely dramatic Oscar nominated performances (Oscar went to John Wayne 'True Grit', big mistake in my opinion). The performances add significant weight to the whole film.Midnight Cowboy is a simple motion picture but it covers a lot of issues whether social, psychological, emotional or moral. It is about the decaying structure of America, it is about poverty and its harrowing effects, it is about a city with no hope plagued by drugs and crime, it is about a modern society with some weird, disgusting personalities; in many ways this film reminds me of Scorsese's Taxi Driver, although the films do differ slightly, they also share some similarities. Paramount to the story is friendship and trust and its importance in life in whatever social and economic tier you find yourself in.Is the film dated? Yes and no. New York City is a much safer, cleaner city today however the film touches on timeless issues; poverty, friendship, struggle and homelessness.A masterful film, powerfully executed.9/10

Although I love this movie, I can barely watch it, it is so real. So, I put it on tonight and hid behind my bank of computers. I remembered it vividly, but just wanted to see if I could find something I hadn't seen before........I didn't: that's because it's so real to me.Another "user" wrote the ages of the commentators should be shown with their summary. I'm all for that ! It's absolutely obvious that most of these people who've made comments about "Midnight Cowboy" may not have been born when it was released. They are mentioning other movies Jon Voight and Dustin Hoffman have appeared in, at a later time. I'll be just as ruinously frank: I am 82-years-old. If you're familiar with some of my other comments, you'll be aware that I was a professional female-impersonator for 60 of those years, and also have appeared in film - you'd never recognize me, even if you were familiar with my night-club persona. Do you think I know a lot about the characters in this film ? YOU BET I DO !!........and am not the least bit ashamed. If you haven't run-into some of them, it's your loss - but, there's a huge chance you have, but just didn't know it. So many moms, dads, sons and daughters could surprise you. It should be no secret MANY actors/actresses have emerged from the backgrounds of "Midnight Cowboy". Who is to judge ? I can name several, current BIG-TIME stars who were raised on the seedy streets of many cities, and weren't the least bit damaged by their time spent there. I make no judgment, because these are humans, just as we all are - love, courage, kindness, compassion, intelligence, humility: you name the attributes, they are all there, no matter what the package looks like.The "trivia" about Hoffman actually begging on the streets to prove he could do the role of "Ratzo" is a gem - he can be seen driving his auto all around Los Angeles - how do you think he gets his input? I can also name lots of male-stars who have stood on the streets and cruised the bars for money. Although the nightclub I last worked in for 26 years was world-famous and legit, I can also name some HUGE stars that had to be constantly chased out our back-street, looking to make a pick-up.This should be no surprise today, although it's definitely action in Hollywood and other cities, large and small. Wake-up and smell the roses. They smell no less sweet because they are of a different hue.Some of the "users" thought "Joe Buck" had been molested by his grandma. Although I saw him in her bed with a boyfriend, I didn't find any incidence of that. Believe-it-or-not, kids haven't ALWAYS had their own rooms - because that is a must today should tell you something kinda kinky may be going-on in the master-bedroom. Whose business? Hoffman may have begged for change on the streets, but some of the "users" point-out that Jon Voight was not a major star for the filming of "Midnight Cowboy" - his actual salary would surprise you. I think he was robbed ! No one can doubt the clarity he put into his role, nor that it MADE him a star for such great work as "Deliverance". He defined a potent man who had conquered his devils and was the better for it: few people commented he had been sodomized in this movie. The end of the 60s may have been one of the first films to be so open, but society has always been hip.I also did not find any homosexuality between "Ratzo" and "Joe" - they were clearly opposites, unappealing to one another. They found a much purely higher relationship - true friendship. If you didn't understand that at the end of the movie, then you've wasted your time. "Joe's" bewilderment, but unashamed devotion was apparent. Yes, Voight deserved an Oscar for this role - one that John Wayne could never pull-off, and he was as handsome in his youth.Hoffman is Hoffman - you expect fireworks. He gave them superbly. Wayne got his Oscar. Every character in this film was beautifully defined - if you don't think they are still around, you are mistaken. "The party" ? - attend some of the "raves" younger people attend.....if you can get in. Look at the lines of people trying to get into the hot clubs - you'll see every outrageous personality.Brenda Viccaro was the epitome of society's sleek women who have to get down to the nitty-gritty at times. If you were shocked by her brilliant acting, thinking "this isn't real", look at today's "ladies" who live on the brink of disrepute....and are admired for it.The brutality "Joe" displayed in robbing the old guy, unfortunately, is also a part of life. You don't have to condone it, but it's not too much different than any violence. "Joe" pointedly named his purpose - in that situation, I'd have handed-over the money quicker than he asked for it. That's one of the scenes that makes this movie a break-through, one which I do not watch. I get heartbroken for both.....John Schlesinger certainly must have been familiar with this sordidness to direct this chillingly beautiful eye-opener- Waldo Salt didn't write from clairvoyance. Anyone who had any part of getting it to the screen must have realized they were making history, and should be proud for the honesty of it. Perhaps "only in America" can we close our eyes to unpleasant situations, while other movie-makers make no compunction in presenting it to the public. Not looking doesn't mean it isn't there - give me the truth every time. Bravo! to all......

Review title: Going big from small is not easy
Review_body: A film about an ordinary little man from a small town who wants to realize his dream of a comfortable life in a big city. The real reality is completely different. I liked the idea as well as the performances of the fva lead actors however some scenes bothered me. Through flashback we see certain segments from the past, but we can't be sure what exactly happened. I also much prefer the first half of the film where we see a joint "journey" through a relentless metropolis. In the second half of the film, we have some scenes that differ from the film in a different way of shooting, so the film lost a bit of my overall impression. In the context of winning important Oscars, I must admit that I expected a little more.

Review title: Not as dark as you've heard
Review_body: Unjustly and erroneously rated "X" upon release due to homosexual content, this is at its core a familiar, sentimental story about love and friendship. The narrative is progressed, however, by moments of unconventional imagery, and there are enough such moments to justify calling it an art movie. These moments can be disturbing, particularly the rapid-fire flashbacks and flash-forwards that play in the mind of Jon Voight's faux cowboy character. Traumatic memories and violent urges occupy his mind, though on the outside he seems relatively cheerful. Conversely, his unhappy friend Rico (an amazingly good Dustin Hoffman) has daydreams that are light and escapist. These dissimilar people make a good pair, and the nature of their friendship is tantalizingly ambiguous. The film is certainly dark, but thanks to likable characters and a lot of wry humor the darkness is not unrelenting or oppressive.

Review title: "I'm Goin' Where the Sun Keeps Shining Through the Pouring Rain"
Review_body: I first viewed this film as a college student when it was released some 52 years ago. As in the case of Joe Buck, but in a very different way, the world lay at my feet for the taking, or so I thought, and, as in the case of Joe Buck, was I in for the shock of a lifetime. More than half a century later and after many viewings, this classic monument to an entire era of American history has never lost its visual impact. Although it does struggle in the middle to maintain its initial visual stimulation, it surely comes through at the end to deliver a lasting impression. It is one of those movies that lures the viewer into the action by some very skillful directorial and photographic techniques.As good as Jon Voight and Dustin Hoffman are as the lead actors, and they are indeed both superb here, this film is truly the triumph of director John Schlesinger, who meticulously attended to every minor detail in its contribution to the overall product. If you only regard the impact of the one-scene characters, and there are many here including the bus passengers and the pedestrians on the streets of New York, and the careful placement of individual shots, you will realize how much Mr. Schlesinger as director is essential to the success of this movie. It doesn't hurt to have the talents of Voight and Hoffman, never to be underestimated, and not one but two of the greatest movie theme songs of all time, both John Barry's timeless instrumental and Fred Neil's "Everybody's Talking", sung by Harry Nilsson. Above all, however, it is Mr. Schlesinger's directorial brilliance, including his ability to put it all together, which truly distinguishes this gem as the great film it is rather than just another mildly interesting movie depicting the turbulent and troubling era of the late 1960's. Be forewarned because much of the action is indeed disturbing and often displeasing to the eye, at least to my eye, but Mr. Schlesinger has the ability to submerge the viewer into a cinematic spell so that we just want to keep watching, even when it hurts to do so and when we know the final outcome after many viewings.

John Schlesinger's Oscar winning film is a romanticized country mouse-city rat tale set in a gritty NYC and it benefits greatly from the performances of Jon Voight and Dustin Hoffman. Thanks to them and Sylvia Miles the film is memorable. Voight's Joe Buck and Hoffman's Ratso Rizzo are a modern day Oliver Twist and Artful Dodger. Pure at heart, they're two innocents in an otherwise cruel and indifferent world. Miles, Voight and Hoffman earned well-deserved Oscar nods, but the film itself is uneven and episodic, and much of what happens to Ratso and Joe Buck feels arbitrary and unlikely; the psychedelic party is an attempt to seem contemporary while telling a basically old fashioned story. John Schlesinger's flashy directing is clever but distracting, and the intrusive flashbacks are confusing.

That is the story of the classic "x" rated movie "Midnight Cowboy" "Midnight Cowboy" told us the story of Joe, a man who came from a little of USA to big NY. He i now with an old bag, a radio and much dreams. "He is a hustler, there is a lot of people in NY who wants him" ... well, that is what he think. When he came to NY, he mets Ratso (I mean... Rico). Review title: In My Top Ten of All Time!
Review_body: This masterpiece from early '69 made me want to be an actor.  Easily Schlesinger's best film and a surprise winner at the Oscars.  Nice follow-up to THE GRADUATE for Dustin Hoffman and as the rumpled, dirty little Ratso from the Bronx, he gave his best performance.  Jon Voight is perfect as the "Texas Stud" full of naivete and wide eyes in the big city.  Able support from Sylvia Miles, Bob Balaban, and Barnard Hughes.A 10 out of 10.  Best performance = Jon Voight.  X-rating changed to R-rating after Oscar win (shows how valuable those ratings aren't).  The book is even grimier than the film, but it's definitely not a promotion for New York City (especially then).  Rich, involving and real humanity breaks through by the end of this journey.  Don't miss it!

First off Jon Voight wow! and Dustin Hoffman too they were great together but Voight absolutely carries this. He is the youthful optimist who does right by his mate in there quest for the American dream as the swinging 60s turned sour.John Schlesinger has directed a stone cold masterpiece here with New York pace and style. I felt ill watching Rico get sicker. I was living in the squalor and felt the hopelessness of it all and at the same time laughed with them too. What a great film and a great job to all involved. Bravo!

At first, I didn't know what to think of this movie except that it has good ratings and is a classic.Then, upon watching it, I still didn't quite know what exactly to think of it...except, that it's good.While I was in the US Navy, I've seen all sorts of hustlers on the streets of New York City (card games); Philadelphia (walnut shell games); etc., but, this guy, Texas-Cowboy Joe Buck (played by Jon Voight), went right to the top with male prostitution...hustling rich married women; but, he was a failure at first and actually paid the women in the end!?!?THEN, he meets a semi-crippled New York-Italian hustler named 'Ratso' (played by Dustin Hoffman), and, everything begins to come together.I really enjoyed this movie, and, I also felt so badly for how, even though Ratso is a 'RAT,' he visited his daddy's grave site and mourned over his passing.Deep-down, both of these characters are 'good people,' but, because of the life they've each been handed, they both found a 'cruel and deceitful living' in a cruel and deceitful world; and, it paid-off when they found one another.I highly recommend this movie.

In a time when a lot of superb movies about New York were made (Taxi Driver(10/10),French Connection(10/10),Death Wish(9/10),Shaft(8/10),Marathon Man(9/10),Mean Streets(7/10)) Midnight Cowboy is one of the best.There are a lot of similarities in these movies:All play in New York,all have great acting and rely on these performances,all of them show the dark side of the city with lonesomeness and crime as main stories and all have great music scores,except French Connection which doesn't seem to have one.The story of Midnight Cowboy is pretty good,but what makes it a really good movie is the score,the pictures of New York in a time when it was a dump and especially the acting by Dustin Hoffman and Jon Voight. Voight is a naive cowboy from Texas who wants to become a gigolo in the biggest and loneliest city in the world and Hoffman plays a poor invalid kid from the Bronx,always scamming and stealing. The way that the two are stuck together is beautifully filmed.New York is shot in the most dark way,mostly at night (just like the other movies written above).This makes for an even sadder picture which is topped by a sincere but also sad score with a beautiful harmonica through it.Each scene has something nice to offer and they are all very different and complete the story line,there are no loose scenes. Of course,since it is 1969,there is also a pretty psychedelic sequence in the latter stages of the movie.Although the end is not very satisfying (like most other movies written above),it still makes for one of the best movies ever. 9/10

Review title: Wow! number 2 on my never before seen classics to watch list is a winner!
Review_body: Well number 2 on my list of never before seen classics is a winner! Throughout my life i had only seen bits and pieces of this film, however the saying is...good things come to those who are patient. I think the word awesome is not enough to define the jobs that both Voight and Hoffman do in this compelling drama of a naive male prostitute a.k.a. drifter Joe Buck (Voight) who hears all the money he can make on the streets of New York cause "All the men are tutti fruity's" As he puts it and "their horny rich wife's will be starving for it" hence the word "naive". Joe makes his way to New York from Texas and eventually meets up with a sickly dirty homeless drifter named Ratso (Hoffman) and a friendship ensues as Joe makes what he can to support and nurture the sickly and crippled Ratso. For a movie that was the first they say to be rated x, as to which i can't understand why however those were the times that on film even brief nudity and very mild language were a no-no! I think i'm not being too bold to state that this also paved the way as being one of the very first "gritty" films that pulls no punches showing life on the streets of N.Y. for an average street hustler. This film also did OK at the '69 Oscar awards winning Best Picture of the year as well as winning the best director and writing awards. For a guy who really never enjoyed any classics, i am now looking forward to number 3 on my list.

Originally X-rated, `Midnight Cowboy' was released in 1969 and it was believed that due to its strong subject matter, male prostitution, the film deserved a strong rating. Nearly 34 years after its theatrical release, the MPAA has afforded the film a new R-rating, and it suits the film far better than its former rating. Directed by John Schlesinger (`The Next Best Thing') and starring John Voight (`Holes') and Dustin Hoffman (`Confidence'), `Midnight Cowboy' is a film that gives its audience moments of pause and reflection not only on the issues that it addresses, but also on other social wrongs that exist in society, even after 34 years.	`Midnight Cowboy' is the story of Joe Buck (Voight) who leaves his sleepy little Texas town for the lights of New York City. Naturally, like any young, naïve person, he dreams of making it rich in the big apple.' But his means of achieving that end are as irrational as the day is long-being a gigolo. When he arrives in the city, he encounters a slightly crippled man named Enrico Salvatore Rizzo (Hoffman). After a few miss-encounters with the wrong people, the two become friends and Buck moves in with Rizzo. As such, Rizzo becomes Buck's pimp, to a certain degree, as they try to squander any money possible on the mean streets of New York. 	One can look at `Midnight Cowboy' and simply say that moral is to avoid prostitution-but it's far more than that. The film questions choices we make in life and the roads we choose to go down that may seem enticing, but ultimately lead to what could possibly be a person's defeat. Apropos, this is the situation that Buck encounters in New York. He thinks he's not a great cowboy, but as he would put it, `I'm one hell of a stud!' He's a young man, in his mid to late twenties, and naturally has dreams of being a woman's greatest sexual desire. But at what cost? He doesn't realize the detrimental affect that his actions could have on his life. He's going to have to beg for cash. What's more, the film was made during a time when the sexual revolution and drug use were at their zenith, but to the gullibility of the filmmakers, the issues of STDs and the AIDS virus weren't brought up in the film, as they were primarily unknown to the general public.	Performances in the film were excellent. Hoffman gives a sad portrayal of a man at the end of his rope, with no money, a terrible apartment, and to make things worse he's loosing the use of his legs and he's developing pneumonia. Voight's presentment of the character Buck is superb. Buck is extraordinarily ignorant in his pursuit of his dream, but no more ignorant the Hoffman's character, Rizzo. Rizzo's dream becomes the vision of Buck, as well-going to Miami and basically living off the fat of the land.	Outstanding direction from Schlesinger makes `Midnight Cowboy' a must see. With his uses of quick cuts in the film, lighting, and the gritty atmosphere of a once dingy New York City, Schlesinger provides a dark feel to subject matter. 	`Midnight Cowboy' is not a film for the faint of heart. Modern films that deal in the ideas of the downfall of dreams and degradation of the worlds we inhabit would be `Requiem For A Dream,' and `Summer Of Sam.' As for `Midnight Cowboy,' it's an extraordinary film about characters that suffer from their own downfalls and from their own naïveté. ***1/2

Review title: It was moving, but not for everyone.
Review_body: Indeed, what I just saw was a great movie with a heart. All the superior performances and superior editing/presentation made it worthy for the academy award. But there is more than these.For each view of this film, you'd have to choose your position between the doctor and the patient.
